hypothetical scenario imagine you're a researcher doesn't really matter what kind of
researcher but what does matter is that you've come up with a hypothesis as an exciting hypothesis one that you think
could have a big impact if it can be proven what you need now is data lots of it to see if your hypothesis
holds the data of course must contain the information fields that you need and should ideally span multiple
jurisdictions time frames and demographics to see if your hypothesis is widely
applicable you suspect that there are lots of potentially relevant data sets so there and sure enough you find many
data sets but the problem you quickly encounter is that they don't conform to any common standard because they were
created by different people at different times often for different purposes they can use different names to mean the same
thing and different names uh the same name to mean different things they can
use different units of measurement and different scales some values can be represented as
continuous variables While others use discrete Vari discrete categories and even when categories are used their
values might not align across the data sets instrument or sensor readings can
be skewed from data set to data set because different instruments were used which may have been calibrated
differently these issues make it very hard for you to filter and combine the data across the different data sets or
to do any sort of meaningful analysis across the super set of the data each data set might be fine on its
own but they don't work well together they are discordant
so you need to make your data sets play nice together minimize the conflicting standards you need to harmonize them you
focus on the information that the data sets have in common that you care about and you convert this information to a
common standard if possible harmonization can be a lot
easier said than done sometimes it's easy like giving a variable a standard name and sometimes
it's impossible like when key information fields are missing and can't be imputed sometimes it's possible but
you'll lose Fidelity of the data like when you try to align continuous with categorized variables and sometimes it's possible
but complicated like when you try to align readings from differently calibrated
instruments often harmonization is an iterative process look for the 8020 Rule
and find a handful of variables that when aligned will give you most value for the least cost and then iterate
decisions need to be made data set by data set variable by variable you need to make tradeoffs with your researcher
goals in mind it's not always easy which is why we love our statisticians and data scientist but our goal is to
provide a great platform to help these good folks do their job so here is our recommended
approach start by storing your raw Source data sets in S3 S3 allows you to secure your data
through encryption and access policies and once your data sets are in S3 you can do all sorts of cool things with it
we're also going to store the harmonized version of each data set in S3 once we've completed the harmonization
process you'll want to code your harmonization processes in python or R these languages are de facto standards
for data exploration and manipulation and they're very familiar to data scius
and they're huge communities where you can get help for many common problems in jibit notebooks is a very
nice open-source web application for integrating your documentation your exploratory analysis and your
harmonization code into self-contained notebook artifacts and you can share
these notebooks with the researchers who are going to consume your harmonized data in fact you can even publish The
Notebook itself in S3 along with the harmonized data sets that it generates this will unambiguously Define how the
harmonization was done in a way that anybody can review and reproduce for
themselves Apache SP is a fast th memory distributed compute engine that lets you easily scale your
data and compute workload across clusters of multiple nodes spark can be programmed easily with python and with r
and it gives you access to a rich set of data manipulation and machine learning libraries which makes it a great platform to address the full gamut of
harmonization challenges and Amazon EMR provides
clusters in the cloud that can run a paty spar the Clusters can be sized to handle the compute workload for whatever
size and number of data sets you need to harmonize spark running on EMR clusters
can easily access the source data sets that we've stored in S3 your harmonization code should also
save its output the harmonized version of those data sets to S3 as well for researchers to later access and
analyze so now that your data sets have variables that are called the same thing
and that mean the same thing you'll want to make them easily searchable you and other researchers
need to be able to find the data that are relevant to your hypothesis so spin up an Amazon elastic
search cluster with a few more lines of code in your harmonization notebook you can
easily save the harmonized data that you want to search on to an index in the elastic search
cluster and you can build a web search UI similar to the one that was shown here from our chample app that will let

needs okay so using the search capability we've now located several harmonized data sets that you want to

spot instances all your data sets stay safely stored in
S3 this separation of storage and compute gives you the flexibility to size and resize your compute cluster as
you need and it also means you can shut down your EMR cluster when your analysis jobs are
done and you won't lose your data as we discussed when we talked about
harmonization you can use notebooks to encapsulate your analysis code with its output to create Beautiful live

others here's an alternative way for doing your analysis attractive if you're more comfortable with relational

lets you Define relational database tables to describe your data which stays stored in S3 your harmonization notebook
can be made to automatically Define a of tables for you so that when your harmonization is done you can
immediately start running SQL queries on the Athena console or from SQL clients or bi tools such as
Tableau Athena is one of our serverless services which means it's just always
available you don't have to worry about sizing clusters or anything like that and you pay only for the queries you
run and speaking of serverless services you'll also want to try out Amazon quick
site quick site is our business analytics service it's compatible with a
wide variety of data sources including Athena this means that within minutes
you can connect quick site to your data sets in S3 via Athena and create beautiful charts and
tables to reveal patterns and relationships in the data quick site includes an in-memory
calculation engine called space space lets you build really fast interactive visualizations and
dashboards and with quick site you can create stories that allow you to reveal your insights in a logical progression
interactive storyboards and dashboards can easily be shared with others in your
organization so we've talked about why and how you can harmonize search and analyze your data sets on AWS let's take
a quick look at how we can pull these steps together into a complete
architecture starting with harmonization the harmonization process is executed on an Amazon EMR cluster
running in your VPC the cluster has a Pache spark in Jupiter installed so that once it's
running you can securely connect to the Jupiter notebook server from your web browser and start creating
and running harmonization notebooks your harmonization code reads the source data sets from S3 transforms
the variables and values as needed and writes the harmonized versions of your data set back into
S3 when you're done harmonizing you can download and see your notebooks in your source code management system and then
you can terminate the EMR cluster there's no sense paying for it when you're not using it and you can always spin up another cluster when you need to
run harmonization again to add a search and Discovery
portal for your data sets create an Amazon elastic search domain use the harmonization process to
index the data that you want to make searchable elastic search has a connector for aache spark that makes it
really easy to efficiently bulk save the data that we want to search directly from The harmonization
Notebook to create a web UI search page we can host the required components as Docker containers in the Amazon ECS
service the UI should be deployed across two availability zones in your VPC to ensure fault
tolerance an application load balancer can be used to provide a single URL entry point and you can run search UI as
a standalone site or integrate it into your existing website
add atha and quick site to the architecture to provide the ability to create and share analysis of your data
